In Blue Shift, you play Barry Calhoun, the security guard featured prominently in HL2 and briefly in the first game. Basically, in Blue Shift, your goal is to escape. Barry meets up with various scientists until he finds Dr. Rosenberg who tasks him with setting up a teleportation machine to escape outside of main Black Mesa compound, other scientists are with Rosenberg as well. The story is rather short, about 2 hours to beat if you bum rush it and play on easy, which is what I did. But it was still fun as it expands on the Half Life universe and you get to hear other characters talk about Freeman and even Shepard, the guy from Opposing Force.

Graphically and technically, Blue Shift has not aged well. The textures are pretty terrible and Barry slides like crazy after letting go of "w". It's kind of annoying. I can't blame the devs for the textures though, the game is rather old. But the wasd controls are so clunky. At least the level designs were still great.

Pretty good game, super short story though. And I wasn't as invested as I could have been.

Half-Life: Blue Shift is the second of two standalone expansions that Gearbox developed for Half-Life. Like Opposing Force, you won't be playing as Gordon Freeman in this one. Instead, you'll be seeing the Black Mesa Incident from the point of view of Barney Calhoun, a security guard who you may already know if you played Half-Life 2 first.

The thing to know about Blue Shift is that aside from having its own campaign, it adds absolutely nothing. No new weapons, in fact less than either of the previous iterations. No new enemies, again less than Opposing Force. You don't even get a new boss fight. On top of all that, it's short, only three hours (or less).

The one thing Blue Shift adds is the High Definition pack, which overhauls (some) models and textures and can be applied to both Half-Life and Opposing Force. It does a decent job of bringing Half-Life's looks up to standards (for 2001), but some dislike the changes it makes to certain things unnecessarily. Some say it changes the feel of Half-Life. I wouldn't go that far, although there was literally no reason to change the MP5 to an M16. Some might like it, some might not.

Seems like I'm pretty hard on Blue Shift, and it's true, when it was released a lot of people hated it. Having said all that, Blue Shift isn't bad, per se. It's basically just more Half-Life. One thing, I don't know if this was just me, but one of the interesting things about Blue Shift is that while Hard Mode in Half-Life meant that you were never going to have enough health, Blue Shift's hard mode seems to extend that to ammo. That means that until you start fighting marines later in the game, it almost feels like a survival horror game. This is very enjoyable, and adds a difference of feel from Shephard or Freeman as playable characters.

Blue Shift isn't bad, it just isn't much. I wouldn't say it's worth buying on its own, but if you buy it with the Anthology pack, it's a decent extra.

初代Half-Lifeの追加シナリオですね。
時間軸はHalf-Lifeでゴードン・フリーマンがBLACKMESA研究所に出向くオープニングと全く同じ時間にはじまり、
研究所の警備員「バーニィ・カルフーン」が主人公のアザーサイドストーリーです。
BLACKMESAで起きてしまった実験の失敗に拠る異次元からのエイリアンの侵攻を別視点で描きます。
バーニィは続編のHalf-Life2でも重要なサブキャラクターとして登場します。
Half-Lifeのオープニングで冒頭に最初に映り込む警備員がバーニィ・カルフーンです。
さて、肝心のゲーム内容ですがボリューム自体は少なめ。ゆっくりプレイしてもクリアまで３～４時間程度でしょうか。
ただ、スケールの小さい作品なりにHalf-Lifeの要素である物理パズルや謎解き、異世界Xenステージなどエッセンスは上手く纏めてある印象です。恒例の「トレーニングモード」はHalf-Lifeと全く一緒でした。
主人公はHalf-Lifeの主人公が身につける特殊なスーツ（HEVスーツ）を着ていませんのでHEVスーツのシールド回復器ではシールドを回復できません。
名誉の戦死を遂げた仲間が落とすプロテクター＆ヘルメットを取るとシールドが回復します。
シールドの回復手段など本編とは微妙な違いがありますが、操作感覚はまったく一緒ですね。特に新規の武器などは無いです。
ゴードン・フリーマンの相棒であるバールも出てきますが、今回銃弾は潤沢にありますのでわざわざ弾丸の節約の為のバール攻撃は必要ありませんでした。
主な目的は、BLACKMESA研究所に残った研究員を救出援護しつつ、エイリアンや情報隠蔽に派遣された特殊部隊の攻撃から生き延び脱出することです。
終盤では特殊部隊に襲われて気を失い両側から引き摺られるゴードン・フリーマンの姿が確認できます。
Half-Life1がなくてもプレイは出来ますが、細かい演出の意図などはわからないでしょう。
逆にHalf-Lifeをやりこんだ人ほどキャラクターの交差、別視点でのHalf-Life世界の楽しみ方が出来ると思います。
開発は、Borderlandsシリーズでお馴染みのGearsBoxSoftwareが行っています。

Whats this? A NEGATIVE Half-Life game review? Best to downvote it and not read it. As long as something has Half-Life in the title it can't POSSIBLY be shit! No. Boring at best and flat out bad at worst Blue Shift has the honor of being Half-Life's red headed step child (No offense to red headed step children.). Many will assume that because it's related to Half-Life it's good or that because it's a expansion much like Opposing Force which is considered to be one of the best expansions ever made. Opposing Force was pretty damn good as far as expansions go so this being the Yang to Opposing Forces Yin is disappointing. 

If Half-Life were The Terminator and Opposing Force was Terminator 2 then Blue Shift would best be decribed as Terminator 3. Blue Shift came 4 years after Half-Life and 3 years after Opposing Force. Very little has been done and a lot has been taken away or miserably mimicked from the prior titles with the only worthwhile thing to come from this other than an HD model pack was that now one of the many Barney's has been given the last name Calhoun meaning that THIS of all things is canon.

First the positive. The best thing about Blue Shift is it's built upon Gold Source (Really stretching here). While the places you fight the HECU are the highlight of the game because they are ONLY fun thing in the whole game and even then these areas are poorly designed as their placement is poor/careless/haphazard. The HD pack is also a good option to toggle between having on or off. And it's short (A blessing and a curse all considered). I guess it does try something new in regards to having constant interaction with a single NPC named Dr.Rosethal (or something) later in the game but thats about it.

Ho boy onto the bad. Blue Shift feels like someone released an unreleased game that had cancelled early in development with nothing but it's basic skeleton finished, waiting for the meat and muscle to be added prior to the afformentioned cancellation. Released in 2001 and yet free mods have larger more impressivley designed areas, setpeices and scripted sequences for free. It has dull puzzles, and uninteresting story that says nothing new, the game is short yet has a lot of it's lenght taken by REALLY bad Xen levels, and it has lengthy PAINFUL sewer levels early on that very few of my friends have ever even gotten the motivation to get past to this day. It's worst offense is how it fails the core attraction and appeal of Half-Life which is to feel like you have been put into a real/tangible location. Thanks to how bad and bizzare the layouts are past the short opening before the elevator this is failed epicly. Nothing interesting happens. Funnily enough this is far from the worst FPS I've ever played (Chaser and Medal of Honor: Underground for the GBA come to mind.) as it is at least stable/functional but it makes the cardinal sin of wasting my time and being so boring as to make you question why you bothered playing it or games in general.

"How could something made by Valve be bad?" you say. Opposing Force and But S h i t were made by Gearbox in addition to an often forgotten COOP addon for a PS2 port of Half-Life that was worked on by Gearbox. I don't dislike it because it's by Gearbox as that would be petty but if you are inclined to defend it for the glory of Valve as opposed to based on his own merits than at least you know it wasn't by them now. Another annoyance is that Barney goes into space aka Xen without any sort of protective gear so who needs a space suit when you can hold your breath right? They weren't kidding when they said the fabric in their dress shirts can really breath.

Opposing Force is one of the few expansions that was not only great but could stand on it's own so may so maybe the expectations for Blue Shift aren't fair. While Opposing Force is non canon dissapointingly all thanks to it's inclusion of badly designed aliens called Race X Blue Shift on the other hand is. That might be because it has no new weapons or aliens though because it's not like anything interesting happens in Blue Shift other than Barney physically escaping before all the interesting shit like the military pulling out could happen (Oh and Shepard gets mentioned for some reason in addition to you watching Gordon get dragged away). Considering the time and location Shepard arrived at Black Mesa it's not to hard to believe that there may be weapons Gordon didn't find as the HECU related weapons that Shepard would come across weren't very common compared to the MP5/M4. No new weapons is sort of excusable having played future titles like Half-Life 2: Episode 1 and 2 but considering Opposing Force was probably made by similar people it's ridiculous that they learned nothing and that there was no variety. 

No Race X? Thats fine. The Race X aliens didn't fit in with Half-Life's aliens and weren't even fun to fight. In Blue Shift the environments were made small for console in addition to already being painfully linear, uninteresting and looking really out of place. They are REALLY flat. You have sewers, parking lots, sewers, storage rooms, parking lots, sewers, parking lots and Xen. That's a lot of variety ey? All the puzzles take forever and the peices for them move slow as hell. The combat encounters are also a  bore and primarily take place in these afformentioned parking lots or a train yard which while outdoors don't seem to be part of the facility thanks to poor cohesion. 

I don't swear often but I must to get to the point and be brash. You are a security gaurd. In Black Mesa. And luckily you are Barney Calhoun out of all of them. Yeah not much is going to happen this should be pretty grounded. Then again this is Black Mesa. Other then the arbitrary showing Black Mesa go to hell during the resonance cascade whats there to show? How many dull fucking puzzles can one gaurd survive? Pubblicato nel 2001, Blue Shift è un'espansione stand-alone di HL sviluppata da Gearbox Software e pubblicata da Valve. E' la seconda di due espansioni: il pg. introdotto, Barney Calhoun, ha un suo sviluppo nella serie di HL. Rispetto al titolo principale e alla prima delle due espansioni, il titolo risulta inferiore dal punto di vista della longevità (3-4 ore a difficoltà normale) e della varietà delle armi, decisamente poche. Presenta però qualche innovazione dal punto di vista del gameplay e della varietà. Il gioco è simile ad HL e mantiene tutti i pregi del gioco originale (trama, fisica, giocabilità...) ma l'assenza di [ATTENZIONE: SPOILER] un vero e proprio boss toglie secondo me qualcosa al finale.
PS: non c'è il doppiaggio in italiano.

Voto: 8/10.

Half-Life: Blue Shift is an amazing, linear game that has you shooting at zombies, headcrabs, headcrab-mounted zombies, and more as a Black Mesa security guard that had survived the horrible incident. The story couldn't be any more creative then it was back when this first game out, and it still warms my heart when I play it to this day. The graphics were a big upgrade back then, introducing all-new transparency to Source-Engine games, something thought impossible when game companies produced games. The style it was introduced in was phenominal, just a different path then just rushing the games out as in today's modern game. All of this is why this game DESERVES this final rating:

+-+-+-+Score+-+-+-+
Originality: 18 / 20
Style: 19 / 20
Story: 19 / 20
Compatibility: 20 / 20
Control: 19 / 20

Total: 85 / 100 - 5 Stars

I extremely recommend that you buy this game!
